Post title: New language pack maintainers wanted
Post description: Dear Moodlers, There are 212 language packs available for Moodle. Translating the Moodle interface is done on a voluntary basis by Moodle community members, Moodle partners, Moodle enthusiasts etc. The lead of every language pack is the language pack maintainer, who checks every contribution to the language pack and releases it to the world. Very often, language pack maintainers do a lot if not most of the translation work themselves. This year I have tried to contact language pack maintainers who seemed to have left. This is normal - people move on with their lives, interests and things to spend time on change. But it's nice if it is clear for everyone if a language pack is not maintained any more. So it's clear now. Check your language on https://lang.moodle.org/local/amos/credits.php . If it is not maintained, read https://docs.moodle.org/en/Maintaining_a_language_pack and if you feel like it is something you would like to do, send me a message and improve the translation you need. Kind regards Koen

Post title: Language translation for child language not loading
Post description: Hello, Moodle community! I recently stumbled upon some (to us) odd behaviour with our Moodle instance. We are currently maintaining several languages, and the customizable translations offered through the language packs have been working great so far. The issue at hand was found by looking at the following three - Norwegian (nb), English (en) and New Norwegian (nn). When changing a certain string (core -> nocourses), the translation loads as expected in NB and EN, but in NN it does not change. I understand that NN is considered a child language by Moodle, and this may explain this mentioned behaviour. I tried searching the docs, code and admin possibilities to change this behaviour but wasnt able to. My question then becomes - how can I make a chlid language (like nn) accept changes to every string?

Post title: New German language package: Community
Post description: We see more and more Moodle systems that are using Moodle courses mostly or partially for communities. The terminology 'course' and' teacher' can create confusion. Koen prepared a new language pack for German this week (thanks) and we started with the adaption. The package Deutsch community (de_comm) is a subpackage for de_du which is a subpackage for de.  Its available in the language system, and can be used in each Moodle system now. What did we change: English German standard German Community Course Kurs Raum Teacher Trainer/in Moderator/in Topic Themenbereich Arbeitsbereich Changes are done only for elements that are visible for students only. Activities that are typically used in teaching/learning situations are not changed. I.e. quiz, assignment, grades. Totally we changed  +260 strings. I think we will have overseen some strings. This will be corrected continously if you send us an information or we see it while using the package. How did we work with this package translation? We opened AMOS language system in two browser windows. In the first window we searched for the term 'kurs' in de-package. In the second window we searched for 'course' in the de_comm package. We had to search  for the english term because the package was empty. Then we worked through all strings and copied the required elements from de to de_comm and changed them or wrote short strings directly into de_comm window. We made this process file by file for core (moodle.php)  and core_admin. In the next step we searched in de_comm for missing strings with 'course' for all standard lang files. As result we got more than 800 strings, but only ~ 100 were relevant. Finally we installed the new language package on a Moodle system and checked several pages. We found a dozen more strings we had to change. The total amount of time for an experencied translator was around 6 -7 hours. For German language we have now four lang packages: Standard German: de = using the formal 'Sie' (you) Deutsch du: de_du = using the informal 'du' (you) Deutsch community: de_comm = using Raum (course) and (Moderator (teacher) and du (you) Deutsch kids: de_kids: simple German for primary schools and students learning German as a second language

Post title: Japanese email addresses
Post description: Japanese email addresses are a problem for moodle due to some of the characters used in many email addresses from docomo and other services. The problem occurs during signup, and during changes to a profile email address. The solution to this problem is to navigate to the user folder in moodle and search out the edit_form.php and editadvanced_form.php files. You will need to remove the portions of the script that deal with validation of the email characters. Remember to backup these files so you can restore them if you make a mistake. The portion of the script that deals with checking to see if an email address already exists or not can be left as it is. This, of course, is not the best solution to the problem, but it is something I can recommend as a temporary solution.

Post title: Notice to all Moodle translators: changes to the quiz language files
Post description: At the moment, all the language strings for the quiz and all the question types are all in one big quiz.php langauge file. Between now and the Moodle 1.7 release, I am planning to move all the question-type specific strings into separate langauge files. For example qtype_multiplechoice.php. Post title: TRANSLATORS: something new about the structure of language packs
Post description: From http://docs.moodle.org/en/Translation#Structure_of_a_Moodle_language_pack In the folder instal/lang/xx you will also find some language packs.
These language packs contain a small summary of each language pack,
containing only the strings needed for the installation process. These
files are generated automaticly every night by the download .moodle.org server and must not be changed manually .
For translators this is a weird experience, since changes you add to
the strings, used in the installationscript, will not be visible before
a new download of your 1.6 installation and after 24 hours. Any questions?

Post description: This is a repost of http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=30192 .  I'm posting it here to see if I get some other suggestions on a fix. I'm
having some problems with instructors posting embedded answer (CLOZE) and short answer questions in Moodle.  This is an example of what they post: Министр
иностранных дел палестинской администрации назвал
{1:SHORTANSWER:=целевые} убийства Израилем {1:SHORTANSWER:=радикалов}
из Хамаса {1:SHORTANSWER:=преступлением}, которое только усилит цикл
насилия. {1:SHORTANSWER:=На} {1:SHORTANSWER:=Западе} растёт
озабоченность, что в случае продолжения насилия, мирный план

иностранных дел палестинской администрации назвал
{1:SHORTANSWER:=&\#1094;&\#1077;&\#1083;&\#1077;&\#1074;&\#1099;&\#1077;}
убийства Израилем
{1:SHORTANSWER:=&\#1088;&\#1072;&\#1076;&\#1080;&\#1082;&\#1072;&\#1083;&\#1086;&\#1074;}
из Хамаса
{1:SHORTANSWER:=&\#1087;&\#1088;&\#1077;&\#1089;&\#1090;&\#1091;&\#1087;&\#1083;&\#1077;&\#1085;&\#1080;&\#1077;&\#1084;},
которое только усилит цикл насилия.
{1:SHORTANSWER:=&\#1053;&\#1072;}
{1:SHORTANSWER:=&\#1047;&\#1072;&\#1087;&\#1072;&\#1076;&\#1077;}
растёт озабоченность, что в случае продолжения насилия, мирный план
{1:SHORTANSWER:=&\#1044;&\#1086;&\#1088;&\#1086;&\#1078;&\#1085;&\#1072;&\#1103;}
{1:SHORTANSWER:=&\#1050;&\#1072;&\#1088;&\#1090;&\#1072;}
может
{1:SHORTANSWER:=&\#1087;&\#1088;&\#1086;&\#1074;&\#1072;&\#1083;&\#1080;&\#1090;&\#1100;&\#1089;&\#1103;}. When

Any suggestions for fixing this or displaying the answer in cyrillic?  The default language for the site is ISO-8859-1 (English) and the instructors are not forcing the language to Russian for that particular course as they have exercises in both Russian and English. Post title: Korean text in Moodle graphs - font file
Post description: Hi language moodlers, Happily, the Korean language pack has recently seen a flurry of translation and it nearing 100% completion (in the strings, not the help files unfortunately). However, I just noticed that the graphs in Moodle, such as in activity reports and survey results, didn't show Korean text properly. In its place was just boxes. After some searching I found the solution - placing a ttf file in the fonts subdirectory of the language pack. I had a look and there are several languages which have included such files there - but none of them are more than 1MB in size. I noticed that for other multi-byte languages such as Chinese and Japanese there was a README file giving instructions where to download the file from, presumably because these files are quite large. Indeed, the smallest Korean .ttf file I could find which looked acceptable is 3MB in size. Do you think that this is too large too include in the language pack? I would ordinarily have no hesitation in just adding a README with download instructions, but the Korean fonts are very hard to find. Opinions welcomed, Tim.

Post title: Multilanguage problems in lessons and quizzes
Post description: I have made a multilanguage course containing a number of lessons and a final quiz. In general it was possible, at least as long as I limit the course to 2 different languages. Though, have made the following observations concerning the different kind of questions within the lessons and the quiz. I have attached a backup of a testcourse I made to show my observations. Lessons Short Answer questions does not accept the correct answer as correct (see testlesson003) Matching questions shows the text in both languages and does not accept correct matches as correct (see testlesson005) Quizzes Multiple Choice questions works correct - but the question text is limited to 255 characters. As the language codes <lang lang="en_US" format="auto"></lang> is 40 characters for each language, this soon limits the number of languages. (see question 1 in the quiz) True/False questions works correct - but it seems that the "True/False" labels are chosen from the last of the stated languages. (see question 2 in the quiz) Short Answer questions works correct if the answer is the same in the different languages, but if the answer is different in the various languages, it does not work (see questions 3 and 4 in the quiz) Matching questions show both languages at the same time in the matches (see question 5 in the quiz) Embedded Answers shows the correct language, but miscounts the results. With 2 languages each language is worth 1 point, but you only get credit for the one you answer in the language chosen. This completes my observations. Would it be an idea to connect the language to the lessons and quizzes instead of the questions within these modules? Kind regards John Raj

Post title: New language pack maintainers wanted
Post description: Dear Moodlers, There are 212 language packs available for Moodle. Translating the Moodle interface is done on a voluntary basis by Moodle community members, Moodle partners, Moodle enthusiasts etc. The lead of every language pack is the language pack maintainer, who checks every contribution to the language pack and releases it to the world. Very often, language pack maintainers do a lot if not most of the translation work themselves. This year I have tried to contact language pack maintainers who seemed to have left. This is normal - people move on with their lives, interests and things to spend time on change. But it's nice if it is clear for everyone if a language pack is not maintained any more. So it's clear now. Check your language on https://lang.moodle.org/local/amos/credits.php . If it is not maintained, read https://docs.moodle.org/en/Maintaining_a_language_pack and if you feel like it is something you would like to do, send me a message and improve the translation you need. Kind regards Koen

Post title: Language translation for child language not loading
Post description: Hello, Moodle community! I recently stumbled upon some (to us) odd behaviour with our Moodle instance. We are currently maintaining several languages, and the customizable translations offered through the language packs have been working great so far. The issue at hand was found by looking at the following three - Norwegian (nb), English (en) and New Norwegian (nn). When changing a certain string (core -> nocourses), the translation loads as expected in NB and EN, but in NN it does not change. I understand that NN is considered a child language by Moodle, and this may explain this mentioned behaviour. I tried searching the docs, code and admin possibilities to change this behaviour but wasnt able to. My question then becomes - how can I make a chlid language (like nn) accept changes to every string?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Marius, The behaviour you describe does indeed seem odd, especially as I notice Norwegian Bokmål (nb) is also a child language pack. Or did you mean Norwegian (no)? You should be able to edit child language packs the same as parent language packs using the Language customisation feature. Can you check if you can reproduce the problem on our Sandbox demo site ? Note that the site resets every hour on the hour, so if you log in just after the hour then you'll have plenty of time to try things out. PS I've moved your post to the Languages forum where our languages experts hang out in case anyone else has encountered the same problem.
Comment 2: Hey, As you changed a text string in Moodle. It updates correctly in English and Norwegian Bokmål but not in New Norwegian. That happens because NN is a child language of NB. There below are some steps that will help you: 1. Go to Site administration – Language – Language Customization. 2. Choose New Norwegian (nn) 3. Find the string 4. Edit it to your custom text. 5. Save Change 6. Go to site administration—Development—Purge all caches.

To allow language selection before logging into Moodle, an administrator can enable language auto-detection or provide a language selection menu on the front page . [1, 2] AI responses may include mistakes. [1] https://www.packtpub.com/en-us/learning/how-to-tutorials/languages-and-language-settings-moodle [2] https://docs.moodle.org/en/Language_settings [3] https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=348272 [4] https://docs.moodle.org/en/Language_settings [5] https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=423917 'SoS', Ken Comment 3: It's one thing to have Moodle detect the language a user's browser is using and then present the interface in their preferred language. It's another to display content applicable to them in their language. I am not sure how you would do that if you have separate courses in French and English. You can use the Multi-language content filter to translate content in the same course so that users will automatically see the content in their chosen language. Comment 4: Thank you all for your feedback. To clarify, I’m working with Moodle 4.4 and the Alpha theme version 2.5.17. I have two separate courses: one in English and one in French. These are not just translations of the same content — each course has its own structure, activities , quizzes, badges, and certificates tailored to its language. My objective is to find a way to display only the relevant course to each user, based on the language they select during registration: English-speaking users should see the English course, and French-speaking users should see the French one. I’m open to any suggestions — plugins, scripts, or theme customizations — that could help achieve this. Thanks again for your support! Comment 5: Hi Abir - assuming I have understood your details correctly, then.... The crux here, is people are not initially enrolled onto the courses, but have to select the course they want and enrol onto it by either self enrolment or payment (or something else). And the key challenge for you is to show the English people the English course and the French people the French course. The way I would go about this, is I would create my own 'Course catalogue page' which would be used to advertise the courses to the users, and I would have 2 versions of this - one for English, and one for French. If you use the Filtercodes plugin: https://moodle.org/plugins/filter_filtercodes you could use a combination of {coursecards} or {coursecards id} or {coursecard id} to show what you want as cards. What you then do is use the multilanguage plugin - https://moodle.org/plugins/filter_multilang2 and use this to set up a differentiated menu item pointing to the 2 pages you have set up e.g. {mlang other}Available courses{mlang}{mlang fr}Cours disponibles{mlang} With this the users would be directed to the relevant course catalogue based on their language selection. Obviously they could still access the other language catalogue page, or the other language courses directly - (if they follow a direct link to it), which we cannot avoid, but hopefully this would get most people to the right place. ---- If your courses are 'self enrolment' then an alternative approach would be to use Cohorts - what you are wanting is to have dynamic cohorts set up so the English people are in a cohort called 'English' and the French people are in a cohort called 'French'. Once you have people in the right cohorts, you can set the self enrolment mechanism up in each of the courses so people can only self enrol if they are in a certain cohort. I don't think we can dynamically create the cohorts based on the user's language setting, but if you add a user profile field called 'preferred language' where they chose either English or French, you could then use either https://moodle.org/plugins/local_cnw_smartcohort or https://moodle.org/plugins/local_profilecohort to dynamically manage the cohorts for you. Obviously, by using a profile field to select language rather than the proper language preference is going to have other downsides, so not as keen on this suggestion. Or - (not sure who hosts your Moodle, and whether they do this or not), but I don't think it would be much work for someone to develop a plugin that dynamically puts people into a cohort based on their language preference (either by forking one of the above, or creating from scratch), so similar to the above, but keeping the use of the preferred language option. Post description: Hi, I try to ask here something already asked in a french discussion , and on lang site , in the hope to have (useful) answers. I have a Moodle site using several languages. I've done some custom translations for French, our main language. These translations are stored in files located in moodledata/lang/fr_local. I'd like to know, for (an)other language(s), which files, and which strings, have a french custom translation, but not (already) one in this language (begining with english)? This would allow to ensure customisations made in french are also made in (an)other language(s), and make them if not already done, to ensure cohesion between languages. How others are doing this? Séverin
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi, Séverin If you have access to that moodledata/lang folder on your server , comparing xx_local folders with a diff tool (I like kdiff3 , but there are several similar tools) would give you a clear view of the files customized on each language and you can dig into each file to see the strings included on each language. Of course there may be a scripting approach to do this analysis and find all the missing customizations, but for our case (3 languages with a few customized strings) this is enough to find all the incoherences quite fast.
Comment 2: Hi Iñigo, Thanks for your answer and proposition. I have an ssh command line access to the server . I like scripts that can be (re)launched when you want, to verify things an easy way. We have a little more than 20 files customized. What i'd like would be to have a list indicating : file, identifier, string for each language, and that would display elements missing in a language comparing to another. Could be a bash or php script... Séverin
Comment 3: Hi, I've tried something with unix command line. To list files and identifiers for english strings (to launch from moodledata/lang) : `grep -rie "^\$string" en_local | cut -d / -f 2- | cut -d = -f 1 > en.txt` To show differences : `diff --suppress-common-lines fr.txt en.txt` Séverin

Post title: Can a plugin developer use AMOS scripts?
Post description: With an AMOS script, you can do bulk operations over language packages. You can copy or move language strings, or even convert legacy HTML help files to strings. I maintain a plugin that is using some language strings from another (soon to be deprecated) plugin. When I copy the strings using an AMOS script, the language maintainers will have less work to do. I tried already to copy one string, but for the moment I do not see results in AMOS. Are AMOS scripts working for plugin developers or how long do I have to wait till the changes pop up?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: unfortunately not. AMOS integrates with the plugins directory - so when you push a new version of your plugin to the moodle.org plugins db, AMOS gets sent a copy of the new lang file at that point, allowing it to load any new strings. AMOS isn't able to pull code directly from your github repo.

The easiest fix is to run the command line tool that checks all your table collations to update them to the proper collation: https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/Administration_via_command_line#Converting_to_the_new_character_set_and_collation Also, I have a post on how to edit these strings to remove the emojis too: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=433774#p1745442 . Emojis are for children and have no business being in the default language pack.

Post title: Test confirmation Mail
Post description: Hello, I cannot find the text-ID for changing the mail, that is send to a user after finishing a test. Is there anyone with a quick guide, where to find this mail for configuration in the languagepack? Regards Larvi
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Larvi, This is the method that I use to find any string in Moodle's English language pack: If you don't already have, download a copy of the Moodle application files to your computer. You can get this from https://github.com/moodle/moodle . You don't need to install it. For best results, use the same version that you are using on your Moodle site. Use a file search tool such as the free version of FileLocator Pro for Windows, or a command line tool such as grep for Linux/MacOS, or even a code editor such as VS Code, to search all of the .php files for a common part of the English version of the string of text which appears in the email. This will enable you to locate the component name and string ID. Do not edit the language files directly as these get overwritten each time you update Moodle or the language pack. Instead, customize the string using Moodle's language customization tool in the instance of your live Moodle site. Feel free to ask if you need help locating a search tool for your operating system. Just let us know which operating system you are using and whether you prefer to use a command line tool or one that is graphical based. Hope you find this helpful. Best regards, Michael Milette

Post title: How to change a language for particular course?
Post description: I have tried the course setting Force language but again i cannot not revert it back to english. How to avail the course in both languages. But dont want to use the site wide language filter functionality. Is there any option to show for end user particular language change.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Gopi, In order to show a course in multiple languages: You must have language packs installed for each language. You must have the appropriate multi-language filter installed and enabled. I recommend the Multi-Language Content v2 plugin as it is easier to work with the plain text {mlang} tags but
you could use the one bundled with Moodle which uses HTML span tags. The course content must be tagged for each language. The content is not automatically translated for you when you switch language. In cases where you cannot use language filter tags, you can use the Restriction by language plugin. This is useful for things like files, folders and URL type activities where
you cannot use language tagging. Force language should NOT be used unless your course is only available in one language on a muti-language enable Moodle site. This feature does not forces the language of the course but the language of the Moodle user interface which in turn can
also display the course in the same language. Assuming you have your Moodle site and your course already setup for multi-language support, switching Moodle's UI language should also change the language of the content of your course. You can force the language of Moodle by adding a lang=xx (where xx is a supported language on your Moodle site) to the URL of your course. This can be useful if you want to give someone a direct link to your course in a specific language. Hope you find something helpful in all of this. Best regards, Michael

Post title: Language customize error Moodle 3.9.2+
Post description: Hi I have installed a moodle 3.9 and the option to customize a language does not appear in site administrator If I put the address /admin/tool/customlang/index.php the following error appears Sorry, but you don't have the permissions to do this (Show local translation). More information about this error × Debug information: Error code: nopermissions × Stack trace: line 870 of /lib/accesslib.php: required_capability_exception thrown line 33 of /admin/tool/customlang/index.php: call to require_capability () any ideas Thank you!!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Marini, The capability it is looking for is tool/customlang:view The first thing I would try is to log into Moodle as an Administrator and use the Purge All Cache option in Moodle. You can do this by going to Site Administration > Development > Purge All  Caches. Then clear the cache and cookies in your web browser. Sometimes these  steps can help. Next, ensure that your web hosting is properly configured and meets Moodle's system requirements. You can easily do this by going to Site Administration > Server > Environment. Ensure that there are no warnings or errors and address any that show up. Make sure that your hosting platform has at least 1-2 CPUs, 1-2 GB of memory if running on a Linux server or 6-8 GB if running on Windows, and 20 GB of free disk space. Ensure that you have a swap file setup. I know a lot of providers hosting on SSD drives don't like this but it will save your site if it runs out of memory. Nobody likes running out of memory or disk space. Check with your hosting service provider to confirm all this. Note that you will need more than this depending on the number of concurrent active users you have and the number and size of your courses. However, if it is just you  and up to about 20 other people right now, you should be fine with the minimum. Next, make sure cron is working and is set to run every 1 minute. You can check this by going to Site Administration > Notifications. If cron is not running regularly, a warning will be displayed on this page. If you don't see anything about cron on that page, it is likely configured and working just fine. If your problem persists, something likely went wrong during or since your Moodle 3.9.3 installation. Did you modify any roles or install any 3rd party plugins? This section of the Moodle code has not changed in 5 years and I use it regularly, so I know it works. If someone installed Moodle for you or you are using a different version of Moodle such as MoodleCloud, Moodle Workplace, Totara or IOMAD, the language editing functionality may be restricted by your hosting service provider. Assuming you installed the regular Moodle 3.9.3 yourself, as a Moodle Administrator, you could try to fix the capabilities yourself by editing/resetting the system roles. If you cannot do this either, I suspect that this may not be the only problem on your site and continuing with it could result in other problems being uncovered down the road which may not be so easy to fix by then. Unless you can determine what caused the problem, as a last resort, you might want to consider simply deleting your recently created site and starting over. Hope you found something useful in all of this. Best regards, Michael Milette

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I haven't looked at the code in question, but from my understanding, the language pack in moodledata/lang/{{language_code}} is managed by the Moodle code and can be subject to a clear out and replacement during any upgrades. If you want to maintain your own local version of the language pack, you should put it in moodledata/lang/{{language_code}}_local (this is where the translations end up if you use the built-in language customisation tool. Any files placed in there should be retained by Moodle and not deleted or overwritten.

Comment 3: Hi, You should look (and read) translation documentation , as a starting point, and all linked pages. Moodle includes a scheduled tasks that updates all installed language packs ; to update, it deletes existing directories, and recreate them with official content downloaded from moodle.org. So you should never make your translation in moodledata/lang/XX but rather in moodledata/lang/XX_local Perhaps what applies best to your case is described here . HTH , Séverin

Post title: Is it best practice to create a new langauge or customise the default one?
Post description: I have identified some changes to several core strings in Moodle. I understand it is possible to simply customise the default language but I am wondering if it would be easier long term to create a new language and keep the core language unchanged. If I later ever need to migrate the language this would also be easier. If this is best practice how exactly do I go about this, I wasn't able to find this information unfortunately.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi John, I'm not sure what you mean by 'I have identified some changes to several core strings in Moodle'. Do you mean core language strings changed and in a way that they are now wrong in the translation? -> in that case the best approach is to change them on https://lang.moodle.org . That way all users of your language benefit from your work and you don't have to maintain it. Do you mean that the wording in the language pack is not according to your needs? -> In that case make the changes locally, using the language tool in your Moodle installation. The changes will survive upgrades of your site and you can move them to other installations too - they are in the moodledata/lang/xx_local folder.
Comment 2: Hi Koen, thank you for that, I was asking about the second option. I can see now where to access this in moodle data, a few more questions on this please if you don't mind. If I delete this en_local folder from moodledata will that simply remove all of the changes and essentially "reset" the language pack I have modified? I am just wondering if it is safer to create a new custom language pack eg. en_johnsversion, install it and make all of the changes there as oppose to the default built in language pack? I couldn't find information about installing a custom language pack so not sure if this is even possible.
Comment 3: Hi John, If you remove en_local folder, it will delete all your personnalization for en language. After that, i don't understand why you'd want to create your own language pack ; can you explain the real aim? If you want to avoid an admin to delete it accidentaly, you can change users/group rights on this folder. If it's because you plan to share it with the community, because your personnalization could be useful for lot of people, i could understand. Comment 5: Yes, that is correct. On update of the language packs (happens daily automatically) or when you update your site to a new version, the _local folders won't be touched. You can also easily make a backup of that folder or copy it to other moodle installations if you want. Since it's all folders and files, it's also easy to merge, modify, ... New language pack versions of an existing language are only created when there is a real benefit for the community.

option into the “edit profile” page. We have just solved this problem. If anyone
is interested to make the preferred language option (into the “edit profile”
page) visible for the admin user, then s/he can do it by changing the

for moodle version 3.5 in line 329 Remove:  if ($user->id < 0) { Add:      $ context = CONTEXT_SYSTEM::instance(); if ($USER->id < 0 ||

diff --

 a/user/editlib.php b/user/editlib.php
index d5bbd1ed4f..bf10f66d5b 100644
--- a/user/editlib.php
+++ b/user/editlib.php
@@ -327,7 +327,7 @@ function useredit_shared_definition(&$mform, $editoroptions, $filemanageroptions
         $mform->addElement('select', 'timezone', get_string('timezone'), $choices);

-    if ($user->id < 0) {

         $lang = empty($user->lang) ? $CFG->lang : $user->lang;
         $mform->setDefault('lang', $lang);

I am used to provide multilang strings for "en" and see the same when I select "en_us" as the language. Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Further troubling discovery: when en_us is selected as the language in the language popup menu in moodlecloud, the multilang filter displays the entry for the first language in the entry not the default language. To be more verbose: I have span tags for de and en in a field. When de or en is the active language, the content is displayed as expected. When en_us is the active language, I see the text for de not en -- en should be shown because it is both the parent language and the default language for this site. If I add a span block for pl before the span block for de, then the Polish text is shown when the active language is en_us. pl is shown as expected when pl is the active language. What is going on ???
Comment 2: I just confirmed that the problem described above is not specific to the moodlecloud. I replicated this behavior in the local Moodle at the university, which I believe is version 2.9.
Comment 3: Thanks for raising this Robert. Reading the code, I have a suspicion. The English (en) is implicit parent of all language packs in Moodle (so if a string is not translated, the English original is used). In most places in the code, if the parent language is reported to be English (en), it is actually interpreted as if there was no parent language. And I believe this is what is happening here. The code here https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/v3.1.1/filter/multilang/filter.php#L101-L108 finds that there is no "en_us" multilang part defined and it does not use the "en" part as expected, but it uses the first one on the list. As a solution, I would recommend to use the English part as the first one in the multilang block.
Comment 4: Thanks for checking the Code, David. I bet you are right about the issue. What you suggest as the solution is actually a workaround. Relatively simple and effective but nonetheless a workaround which will work only if there is a single child language used on a site. I just filed a tracker issue for this: MDL-55197

Post title: Translating course text content
Post description: While I understand the process of using the language packs to support a localized UI, I am looking for a solution for submitting our course content for translation into other languages. Ideally the strings could all be exported in a format, such as XML , sent out for translation and then imported for a second language. Short of that - at least a way to export the text content and some sensible way to bring it back into the course either as a new course in a different language or contained within language tags. Or is there a better solution?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Moodle has the multilanguage filter to allow content which has been translated to be displayed to users according to their language choice - there are also a coupl of additional plugins which take this a little further either by extending that filter or by providing conditional activities based on language choice. I made a small hack to the language filter to allow it to apply to whole <div>s surrounding entire blocks of content which I recently presented at the OER15 conference and will be talking about at MoodleMoot UK/ IE in May. The hack can be found at https://github.com/roelmann/moodle-filter_multilang When we did this ourselves we simply copied the content text out into a word processor to send off to external translation and then brought it back in to the editor and wrapped it in the appropriate language div as required. Besides the technical issues, you may have more difficulty finding a translation service that will be happy to deal with an xml file rather than a basic word processed one, so you may end up converting back and for anyway.
Comment 2: A course can be exported into XML with backup. The XML (also smaller parts like question bank  or glossaries) can be converted into XLIFF using the Rainbow/Okapi tools The XLIFF can be translated with professional ( & free & opensource) translation tools tools like OmegaT The output goes via Okapi back into a moodle backup file This can be imported into moodle with restore. Don't start, if it is one Course. It will take you some hours to understand the software, but if you have 3 languages or more, and if new courses are coming up again and again, this would be the workflow. Translation Agencies know XLIFF - its their standard. The XML->XLIFF->XML software (free open source): http://www.opentag.com/okapi/wiki/index.php?title=Rainbow The translation sorftware (good without XLIFF too, free, open source): http://www.omegat.org/en/omegat.html Here is an English module that explains this in detail (in a German course about translating quizzes).  Use the Guest role to enter. http://www.lern-net.de/mod/scorm/view.php?id=322 Please add some feedback, if you have tried it. Ask google for 'Okapi rainbow moodle' to find some people doing this. Mainly Spanish/Basque area.
Comment 3: Hi Deborah, We use the filter_multilangsecond by Vanyo Georgiev to manage multilingual courses. It supports inline filtering like the original multilang plugin but, like Richard's solution above, it also supports blocks. However, unlike the HTML syntax used in those filters, multilangsecond optionally supports a non-HTML tag syntax. It looks like this in inline: {mlang en}English{mlang}{mlang fr}French{mlang} or like this to encompass entire blocks with any kind of content similar to what Richard is doing: {mlang en} English {mlang}{mlang fr} French {mlang} What our course creators really like about this is the fact that 1) it is a simpler and shorter syntax, 2) they can actually see where the tags are in the editor and 3) they don't need to know HTML. It is so simple that you can sometimes even get translators to add the tags for you. Iñaki Arenaza recently released a demo video of his efforts to take this approach one step further by adding editor integration so that his {multilang en} tags can actually be added using the editor's toolbar. Hope this helps. Best regards, Michael Milette

Post title: List language differences between Moodle versions ?
Post description: Hello, On a M 2.7.1, I recently replaced a given text string about several hundred time in a pack using the Language Customisation tool on Site Admin. Sometimes soon I'll update the site to M 2.7.3, and in a few months from now I'll upgrade it to M 2.8.x Is there an easy way to list the differences between two Moodle versions for a given language pack ('fr' in my case), so that I learn which are the strings that are new, that are dropped, that are changed ... ie which possibly need some work from me on the language personalisation ? Thanks in advance for your suggestions, -michel
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Michel, Between the point versions of Moodle (2.7.1, 2.7.2, ...) there is no versioning done: The language pack evolves on the pace of the modifications of Moodle in that version and the time the language pack maintainer and contributors have to spend on improving the language pack. Those changes can be significant, eg if the language pack was not complete at release time. I don't see any way to know what is changed between point releases, except by checking the logs of the translation portal ( http://lang.moodle.org - login, contribute, logs) or download and keep the snapshots of the language pack and use some diff tool on them. For what is changed between releases (2.7, 2.8) , there is a tool on the language portal to see the current differences for a given language ( http://lang.moodle.org - login, contribute, stage, compare strings at two branches) It's a long time ago since I used the tool for local language pack modification. Doesn't it have a search tool to look for a word in a string? If not, the language portal has one ( http://lang.moodle.org - login, contribute, translator).
Comment 2: Thank you Koen ! When you say "login->contribute" option do you mean "login->translate" option ? -michel
Comment 3: Michel, I think Koen is talking about steps to do in AMOS to compare strings between versions: login, contribute, stage, compare. Nicolas
Comment 4: I am afraid that the tool "Compare strings at two branches" in AMOS is available to lang pack maintainers only to have the overall UI simplified for contributors. However, there should be no problem to make it available to any contributor if requested.
Comment 5: FYI , when comparing the actual contents of the lang packs, you could use the Git repository moodle-langpacks.git that is populated automatically with snapshots of the language pack contents.

Post title: Adding non-core language strings to a custom language pack
Post description: Hi All - Sorry if there is an obvious answer for this, but I could not find one. I want to add some custom language strings to a site - specifically, I want to add some country codes not present in "countries.php". I thought this would be as easy as creating a new custom language pack containing nothing more than a "countries.php" file with the new strings. But, no matter what I do, none of the new strings will show up. I can change existing ones this way with no problem. Is there a correct way to add additional language strings into a language pack? Thanks in advance. Mike
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Moodle now will only recognise strings defined in the base en language pack. The only way to change that would be to modify the string_manager class.
Comment 2: That is unfortunate.... So the only way to add new strings would be to hack core? mike
Comment 3: Well, if you thought the ability to customise the list of countries was generally useful, then you might consider implementing some non-hack way to do so in Moodle core, but otherwise ...
Comment 4: If you add all your English language strings to your theme's lang/en/theme_yourthemename.php these will only show up if they are coded into the theme using somthing like this assuming there is a string called 'helloworld'... 
```text
<?php echo get_string('helloworld', 'yourthemename'); ?>
```
 It was possible to add other language files to themes by copying the en/theme_yourthemename.php and translating it into other languages like French (fr) Italian (it) Spanish (es) German (de) and add theme to your theme lang directory like so...where each file is translated according to the language it needs. 
```text
lang /


      fr/theme_yourthemename.php


      it/theme_yourthemename.php


      es/theme_yourthemename.php


      de/theme_yourthemename.php
```
 But I am not sure now if this is not allowed now. Cheers Mary
Comment 5: Hi Mary - Thanks for your information, but I'm not really sure I'm following... Are you saying I can add new country strings by adding a new file: "/theme/[mytheme]/lang/en/countries.php"? Or are you saying that I can create language strings in a theme with this file: "/theme/[mytheme]/lang/en/theme_[mytheme].php"? If its the latter, this will not solve my countries problem (I don't think). If I understand what you are saying, I would need to recode all Moodle code using countries to use strings from the theme language file? Let me know if I am misunderstanding. mike
Comment 6: I don't think there's an easy solution for this. Generally, defining new strings in a plugin (like via a theme like Mary suggests) works for the `get_string()` usage. But countries.php are handled in a special way. The file acts as a list of known countries, too. And because no language pack (be it a translation or a language customization) is allowed to provide extra strings (i.e. those not defined in the master 'en'), adding more countries into customized countries.php won't work. The cleanest hack coming to my mind is to either customize `core_string_manager_standard::get_list_of_countries()` (as Tim suggests) or to add extra countries to lang/en/countries.php. In either case, you will need to change standard Moodle file.

Post title: Calendar view.php doesn't get put through format_text required for multilang language support
Post description: In Moodle 2.5.1, although event descriptions appear to be filtered, event descriptions are not. As I am working on a multilingual site which leverages multilang without it my content from every language is included. The solution is to change line 127 of /calendar/view.php , replacing: echo $renderer->show_day($calendar); ...with... echo format_text($renderer->show_day($calendar),array('trusted' => true,'noclean' => true, 'para' => false)); What do I need to do to get this change integrated into the core Moodle code? Best regards, Michael
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: That was for the day events. The upcoming events also needs to be fixed. Line 144 of /calendar/view.php also needs to be updated. It is currently: echo $renderer->show_upcoming_events($calendar, $lookahead, $maxevents); To enable multilang language support, it should be replaced with: echo format_text($renderer->show_upcoming_events($calendar, $lookahead, $maxevents),array('trusted' => true,'noclean' => true, 'para' => false)); Best regards, Michael
Comment 2: Hi Michael, Thanks for pointing out an area which is missed by the multi-lang filter, and for suggesting a code solution. Please could you create an issue in the Moodle Tracker for it, then post the issue number in this discussion thread so others can vote, watch and comment on it.
Comment 3: Thanks for the suggestion Helen. I've added the issue in Moodle Tracker: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-41257 Just re-read my original post. The description in Moodle Tracker should be clearer. Best regards, Michael Milette

Post title: New German language package: Community
Post description: We see more and more Moodle systems that are using Moodle courses mostly or partially for communities. The terminology 'course' and' teacher' can create confusion. Koen prepared a new language pack for German this week (thanks) and we started with the adaption. The package Deutsch community (de_comm) is a subpackage for de_du which is a subpackage for de.  Its available in the language system, and can be used in each Moodle system now. What did we change: English German standard German Community Course Kurs Raum Teacher Trainer/in Moderator/in Topic Themenbereich Arbeitsbereich Changes are done only for elements that are visible for students only. Activities that are typically used in teaching/learning situations are not changed. I.e. quiz, assignment, grades. Totally we changed  +260 strings. I think we will have overseen some strings. This will be corrected continously if you send us an information or we see it while using the package. How did we work with this package translation? We opened AMOS language system in two browser windows. In the first window we searched for the term 'kurs' in de-package. In the second window we searched for 'course' in the de_comm package. We had to search  for the english term because the package was empty. Then we worked through all strings and copied the required elements from de to de_comm and changed them or wrote short strings directly into de_comm window. We made this process file by file for core (moodle.php)  and core_admin. In the next step we searched in de_comm for missing strings with 'course' for all standard lang files. As result we got more than 800 strings, but only ~ 100 were relevant. Finally we installed the new language package on a Moodle system and checked several pages. We found a dozen more strings we had to change. The total amount of time for an experencied translator was around 6 -7 hours. For German language we have now four lang packages: Standard German: de = using the formal 'Sie' (you) Deutsch du: de_du = using the informal 'du' (you) Deutsch community: de_comm = using Raum (course) and (Moderator (teacher) and du (you) Deutsch kids: de_kids: simple German for primary schools and students learning German as a second language

Post title: Language customizations lost on upgrade
Post description: Hi all, I've been running a test upgrade of a Moodle 1.9 site to 2.2, and it appears that the language customizations are lost. Looking in the moodledata dir, the "lang" dir gets renamed to "oldlang" and nothing seems to be moved across. Is this expected behaviour, or am I doing something wrong? Thanks for any help!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Yes, this is expected behaviour. The upgrade process just renames the directory with your local modifications of the language pack but you have to prepare the correct syntax for the local string files for 2.x manually (alternatively you can re-edit them via the inbuilt tool that saves them in correct syntax). Note there are several differences in how strings are formatted in 1.x and 2.x, most notably in the $a placeholders handling (must be wrapped in curly braces in 2.x) and no more exceptions for the percentual sign (no more need to have %% in 2.x to display %). Hope this helps.
Comment 2: Hi David, A related question, just to be sure : this is the case when upgrading from 1.9 to 2.x ! But, if you upgrade from 2.0 to 2.2 (for example), do you loose your local modifications (or not, because files are defined the same way) ?
Comment 3: This just affects upgrades from 1.9 to 2.x because there was the syntax change. During the upgrade from 2.x to 2.y, the local customizations are not lost. By the way, if somebody is interested, there is a method in AMOS code that is able to convert strings from 1.x format to 2.x one. Some volunteer might want to use it as a start point for writing a tiny script that would convert all _local packs from 1.x to the new format. See the fix_syntax() definition at https://github.com/moodlehq/moodle-local_amos/blob/master/mlanglib.php#L642

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Joseph, I've just tried the Check out strings into translator button on the QA Testing site and found everything working fine. Hopefully David will notice this thread soon and suggest a diagnosis!
Comment 2: Hi Joseph, when you press the checkout button, Moodle will search for all strings from the core and all plugins and will copy them to the database . The translation tool then works with the strings in the database and the customized strings can be then written back to the files in the local language folders. The initial checkout when there are no strings registered yet in the database may take a longer time. Later checkouts are usually shorter as only the new and modified strings are updated. At all sites I tested the new tool at, the initial checkout took reasonable amount of time - up to twenty seconds or so. At your machine, the script was not able to finish the complete checkout within the maximum execution time defined in your php.ini. The fact it took so long at your machine may indicate that your database performance is not very good and you should consider some performance tweaking. Sure, there could be a progress bar or something to indicate what is going on. And the script could even try to detect the upcoming maximum execution time deadline. Anyway, please try to just re-run the checkout several times. If you have access to your database, try to get the count of already checked-out strings using 
```text
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM mdl_report_customlang;
```
 You should see the increasing number of records after each run of the checkout and you need to reach almost 16000 records before the translation tool can be launched. HTH

Post title: Business-Oreinted language versions?
Post description: It seems to me that Moodle terms are usually directed towards educational usage - either for kids or academic usage. As we use it for business uses, we do change the terms using the language editing interface. However, I was thinking that it would be a step towards Moodle business uses if there business-oriented language packs would be included. Thus, "Teachers" would be "Instructors", "Students" - "Employees" or "Participants". What is your opinion of this? Would it be viable to open such a language pack? Who should I suggest this to?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Amir Elion, Moodles design is in such a way that it is used everywhere for educational purposes it dosent really matter whether its for kids or employees , when they enter moodle they have entered an educational system where the only possible roles for them are student , teacher or an guest, I also think that it gives them an class room like feel. If you think you need to give it a complete official feel for users , Moodle also has an option where you can use it to create custom roles with custom tags to it. I really appreciate the initiative but please do justify the reason for people to work on the new feature(Business class language packs) that you are suggesting.
Comment 2: Dear Ravishankar, I agree that Moodle is a learning environment that can and is being used in various educational and business setting. However, as a training professional, I am aware of the differences between adult learning and children learning, and the different roles expected from adult in the learning process, and from the ones that serve the role of instructors or facilitators. Furthermore, I do not only refer to adult vs. children learning. I also refer to differences between academic and business learning environments. Students in universities are called "Students" because their major interest in that context is learning. However, in a business setting, learning is not an activity on its own, it is one important activity related to the empolyee's goals, skills, etc. As I see Moodle gaining more strength and possibilites in the business world, I thought it might be a good step towards getting Moodle to be more relevant for commercial as well as non-profit organizations. Language is indeed just an "external" characteristic of an application such as Moodle, but still appearance and language do matter and do establish perceptions of such an application. I do think that to include Business-Oriented language packs, would make more organizations willing to consider Moodle as a platform to support business training - either for employees or clients/partners. Obviously, not just external features such as language (and more professional themes for that matter), need to be considered but also more features that support business oriented needs. These can include a more robust integration of online and instructor-led learning (blended learning). Face-to-Face module does provide some of these but I would like to see it and other business relevant modules grow and become more established, and integrated into core. Other examples can include a stronger personal learning plan, stronger report system, and other. It seems some will be addressed by Moodle 2.0. As I am not a programmer, I cannot help with the plug-ins and features. As for the language - I will look at what I have done so far and see if I can take out our specific-company translations and upload it for review if it makes any sense to others. Other opinions on the matter will be welcome...

Post title: A language version for use in schools
Post description: I'm new to Moodle and I'm hoping to role it out to our school over the next few months.  The school has students from kindergarten to Year 12.  I'm wondering if it makes sense to write and use a translation from the standard english version which seems to be more university orientated, to a school version using language that the students are used to.  e.g instead of "Courses" you could use "Year Level" or instead of "Categories" you could use "Subjects" .  Has anyone done this already?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I don't think so. On the other hand you can edit the words in your own Moodle locally by going to site administration>language>language editing >edit words and phrases and there you will fiind all the language files where you can change specific words. Most of the useful and commonly used ones are in the file moodle.php This might be a easy way for you to start off with, although you need to be aware that if you change it in there it changes for the whole of your Moodle, so the word has to be appropriate to all years and subjects.
Comment 2: There is nothing shared on Moodle.org like that, but I can imagine you feel the need to do some modifications for younger children. Edit your language pack only with the Moodle language editor, make sure you make local changes, not language pack changes (local changes is the default behaviour of the editor). That way your changes survive Moodle upgrades since they are stored in moodledata/lang/en_utf8_local I don't think you'll have to do a massive amount of changes, so it is not worth the effort to create and maintain a new language pack.
Comment 3: Hi Neil, Please see the documentation Language editing for further details of what Mary and Koen describe.
Comment 4: We've discussed this for the German language version. Today we've two German language verions one as a standard de_utf8 and a personalized Version using the German 'du' (informal you) instead of 'sie' (formal you). The new discussion started in December a bout a version for primary schools. Specially in a lot of description in moodle.php we think it will be better to describe some terms in an other way and to give a little more orientation. The process started very slow over the last weeks.

Post title: Language styles.php files
Post description: You may, or may not know, that it is possible for languages to include a styles.php file, and then if the current theme specifies both $THEME->standardsheets = true and $THEME->langsheets = true (both of those are the default), then the styles.php file from the language folder will be included with the rest of the standard theme CSS . Well, that was the situation in Moodle 1.9. However, looking in CVS , only Vietnamese includes a styles.php file (last modified in 2005), and that only says 
```text
body,td,tr,li {
 font-family: Arial, Verdana, Helvetica, sans-serif !important;
}
```
 Which looks very similar to the CSS in the standard theme: 
```text
body, table, td, th, li {
 font-family:Arial, Verdana, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
```
 I can't work out why this was introduced. ( http://cvs.moodle.org/moodle/theme/standard/config.php?r1=1.13&r2=1.14 does not help much.) The one thing that might need it is right-to-left languages. However, these days we have a better way to handle that, using an optional rtl.css file in the theme folder. So, I am proposing to remove this functionality from Moodle 2.0. If anyone objects to that, please explain why ASAP. Thanks.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: OK, it turns out that this mechanism was added for the benefit of Vietnamese. Apparently, on Windows computers (at least in 2005 when this was added) Vietnamese text only displayed properly in Arial. Therefore this rule was added so that themes that used another font (e.g. the moodle.org theme) did not make the site unusable in vietnamese.
Comment 2: As discussed in today's jabber chat, my +1 to stop supporting this if we can handle it via standard theme definition. Interesting - in theory, language specific CSS sounds like a really cool feature. Apparently, nobody really needs it. Or can somebody come with an argument why this feature should survive Moodle 2.0?
Comment 3: The advantage of this is that you can keep language specific things with the language pack, rather then in the standard theme. This seems a clean and understandable solution to me. I came accross languages like Inuit and Igbo that are not included in mainstream unicode fonts, so they even need a specific font installed on the computer. I can imagine this feature is necessary/usefull to make these languages work. Anyone aware of other languages that need a specific unicode font to make them work?
Comment 4: By the way, I was noticing today that almost every theme has $THEME->langsheets = false, and in 4 years, it has only been used by one language, so really, I don't feel bad that I took it out yesterday/this morning. It let me remove some rather complex code. Really, it is better gone.
Comment 5: I seem to have come across this discussion too late. Hope it is still active. Re: "(although) language specific CSS sounds like a really cool feature. Apparently, nobody really needs it. Or can somebody come with an argument why this feature should survive Moodle 2.0?" More and more Moodle Themes include a horizontal menubar, which is a really useful feature. But the menu items are specified in a php file which is part of the theme and is not susceptible to the <multilanguage> tag. So ideally we need a theme switcher which installs a different menubar (ie in French) when French is selected as a language. Or is there a simple workaround I have missed?
Comment 6: Themes should be able to have language files like any other bit of code. So the menu should be doing get_string('menuitem1', 'theme_mytheme'); get_string is for internationalisation of code. <multilanguage> is only for internationalisation of user-entered content.
Comment 7: Themes can't have their language packs in Moodle 1.9.7 yet. However, there is a way how to achieve this using the local language packs. See http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=142041#p620514

After filling out the information, the login/signup.php page loaded properly, but with the following error message at the top: Notice : Undefined property: stdClass::$linkIn in /home/site/public_html/lib/moodlelib.php(5473) : eval()'d code on line 1 Notice : Undefined property: stdClass::$linkIn in /home/site/public_html/lib/moodlelib.php(5473) : eval()'d code on line 1 Looking at moodlelib.php, the line in question is the one in bold below: //if local directory not found, or particular string does not exist in local direcotry $langfile = $location.$lang.'/'.$module.'.php'; if (file_exists($langfile)) { if ($result = get_string_from_file($identifier, $langfile, "\$resultstring")) {
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: What is actually going on here is that Moodle is trying to process a language string from one of the language files. The language string contains $a->linkIn, but that variable is not defined. You really need to work out which lang string this is, and where it is being called from.
Comment 2: I guess it is caused by your locally modified language pack. I just searched for all language packs and none of standard Moodle strings accepts $a->linkIn parameter (it also violates our policy of naming variables). Probably you had some local modifications of Moodle code that were replaced during the upgrade but the local string remained.
Comment 3: You can try your luck with the script in this bug MDL-14152 . Just put it in the root of your Moodle site (just for the check and then delete it). It checks all language packs for common errors. The one Tim describes should pop up too. Looking at the code, it checks local language packs too, but I've never tested that.

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Ângelo please start reading Translation first. The $uselocal parameter says the translation tool to save translated string into the xxx_local lang folder, where xxx is the language code - eg. pt_br. All strings saved into xxx_local (aka local lang pack) takes precedence over those in xxx folder (aka master lang pack). The xxx folder is maintained by a lang pack maintainer and you should not modify it directly. If you did so, (1) copy your modified pt_br into pt_br_local, (2) upgrade Moodle and (3) re-save your local lang pack files via lang/admin.php Note since 1.9 one has to explicitly assign herself a capability to save into non-local lang packs. HTH

I would like to be able to develop this course with the appropriate First Nation Font. The font can be located and uploaded from www.languagegeek.com but how do I load it into Moodle so I can write curriculum with this font? Any Suggestions or guidance would greatly be appreciated. Thank you, Simon
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: As I understood from the website, the font is UTF8. That is necessary. You can ask your browser to load the page with that font by changing the theme. See http://docs.moodle.org/en/Theme_basics and http://docs.moodle.org/en/CSS_styles_fonts.css You can replace the fonts for body, table, td, th, li to your font. Off course, the computer used to look at the page will need to have the font installed, so this is only recommended for languages that are not included in a very large (in the sense of containing a lot of characters) font, like Arial or Verdana. I suggest to provide a downloadlink on the start page of the site.
Comment 2: Hi, I have a kind of the same problem here with the Mon language, The Mon font has been used at the basis of the Burmese language, so I can use the myanmar2.ttf font and the Keyman visual keyboard to type it. As a language directory name I now use the mj_utf8 description as there is at this moment no good Iso 639-2 code and Moodle doesn't use three letters but two for the directory names. (I like to see this change to the the Iso639-3 language codes with the utf8 extension like mnw_utf8 with the Mon language) With the help of the Keyman software I now can type the Burmese font in Word and Open Office, but I can't vind a way to display the font. I renamed it as default.ttf and placed it in the fonts subdirectory of mj_utf8 without succes. This is my first non roman font I use with moodle, but please help me as I will need to do this a couple of more times with fonts and languages.
Comment 3: Hi Frans, Moodle can use 3 characters, try it (e.g. fil_utf8 uses 3 characters). The fonts directory has as only purpose to give a home for fonts if Moodle has to generate text on a graph, e.g. in a survey. The display of the texts in Moodle is done client side by the browser. You set the preferred font via the Moodle theme, as described in my previous post, but the computer of the client needs to have that font installed on it. You can't install it through a web application like Moodle. It's great to see Moodle being used to maintain the use of languages with a very small number of speakers, but you will have to make your users install the right fonts, since there is, as far as I know, no general UTF8 font that contains all existing UTF8 characters.

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Ummara are you 100% sure you have put the Russian language pack into the Moodle data folder? Note there are two folders named "lang" in Moodle: The first lang is a subdirectory of the Moodle application root (i.e. the folder where the Moodle source code is installed). This is called Moodle dirroot and is defined in Moodle config.php. The content of this directory should be: /admin /auth ... /iplookup /lang /en /en_utf8 README.txt /lib /login ... You should NOT put any additional language packs into the $CFG->dirroot/lang. Only /en and /en_utf8 are supposed to be there Additional lang packs should be installed into so called dataroot (also defined in config.php). You should see directories like /cache /groups /lang /ru_utf8 /sessions /temp ... there. The $CFG->dataroot/lang is the place you have to unpack downloaded ZIP files into. After this, Russian should be offered as preffered language in your user profiles. Also, you can select it as a default language for your site.
Comment 2: Usually there is no need to download and unzip your language pack manually. Go as administrator to your administration block, language, language packs and use the interface there: left is installed, right is installable. The download and installation should work automatically.

Post title: Encoding of Norwegian

For various reasons the no_NO package will not be deleted, but it will no longer be maintained. The switch to nb_NO poses a few problems: 1. Moodle installations running on servers that still use the obsolete no_NO for the Norwegian - bokmål locale (FreeBSD?) will not be able to show a calendar with the correct date formats, names of days and months etc. for Norwegian - bokmål (Actually, this change has already taken place.) 2. Text tagged as "no" with the multilang tag, will not be recognised as Norwegian bokmål. Today the problem is that you can use two kinds of tags for the same language. Quite confusing I'd say. Are there other problems? Any strong opinions?

Post title: language problems when moving to 1.6
Post description: Hi, We would like to move next year to the 1.6 version and we are checking it now. We are currently using version 1.5.3+ and our local language is Hebrew. While trying to backup some courses in 1.5.3+ and restoring in 1.6 we couldnt see the Hebrew (it was gibberish). While creating a course in 1.6 the Hebrew is fine but when we migrate from one version to the other the Hebrew comes out as gibberish. Any suggestions? Best to you all, Abigail
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: After several attempts to upgrade from 1.5.4 to 1.6 with foreign languages (slovak in our case) we found two possible ways: backups from 1.5 can directly be manipulated - the file moodle. xml in the root of the zipped backup contains all information that needs to be recoded. You need to convert from the old codepage to utf8 and import the zip file with modified moodle.xml. However, if the structure between 1.5 and some newer version would change substantially, this might not be guaranteed to succeed. official way seems to be to keep a copy of 1.5 portal and to upgrade it along with all needed courses to 1.6. Then, these can be backuped and transferred as usual to another 1.6 portal. It is a pity, but it seems to me that officially, backups between 1.5 and 1.6 in foreign languages are incompatible. I would be very glad if someone corrects me.
Comment 2: Thanks for your immediate reply. Abigail
Comment 3: I am working in Spanish as well as Greek, and when we updated from 1.5 to 1.6 we experienced several problems: 1. Curved quotation marks turned into little boxes in all my courses! 2. Links to graphics were lost and had to be reconnected. 3. The editing menus disappeared! 4. Test questions that had Greek fonts mixed the Greek and Spanish fonts, which was a nightmare to correct. Below is my solution I found for that. I quote from another forum entry I made. I am not an expert in this, but I think I found two problems. First, there seems to be some incompatibility between some versions of Internet Explorer and Moodle version 1.6. (This problem did not occur when we were using an earlier version of Moodle, neither does it occur when we used Moodle 1.6 with Firefox .) Secondly, the formatting code also seems to be pretty stubborn sometimes and hard to modify. On Moodle tests, IE seems to pick up the font format from the last of one question and applies it to the beginning of the next question. So when I end one question with a Greek font, the first part of the next question is also in Greek, even if I formatted it in English or Spanish. This included even the work “marks” or “points” for the question. I began to wonder about this when I noticed two things: a. The first questions of all the tests were ok. That is, Greek was Greek and Spanish was Spanish, as it was supposed to be. b. When I looked at any question by itself, clicking the icon of the little magnifying glass, it also looked ok. So what I needed to do was basically clean up the htm code for formatting and make sure the font at the end of each question is not Greek. The best way to clean things up was as follows: a. open the question for editing, b. highlight all the text of the whole question, c. cut it (with shift/delete), d. switch to htm editing mode ( <>), e. delete any formatting code that might still be in the box. f. paste the question back in (still in htm mode), g. switch out of htm editing, h. highlight the words or letters I wanted in Greek, i. change the font to Greek, j. make sure there were at least one or two spaces at the very end that still had the default font (Trebuchet in my case), and k. save the changes.

Post title: glitch with local language pack
Post description: Per advice on this forum, I have created a new language to customize some strings. I called it de_de and set the parent language to de. Replaced de with de_de in the list of languages in sites menu, disabled caching and threw away the old cache file (had to do it otherwise, de was coming back on the menu each time I reactivated cache). Set de_de as the default language. So far so good. When the login screen comes on, de_de is set as default (we force everyone to login) as expected. However, once anyone logs in, the selected language in the popup is not de_de but cs (first language on the list) even though the page is displayed correctly using de_de. But it is confusing to users. This is in 1.4.4+ so I can only hope it works correctly in 1.5. Can I change something so the selection is correct? I won't upgrade to 1.5.x until end of August.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I just spend some time investigating this issue and found the problem. It has to do with the preferable language set by the user. All users that created their profile before I made the change, have the language set (user table, lang field) to de. This makes the current_language() return de not de_de and, of course, since de is longer available among the listed languages, no menu item is marked selected. It seems that the session language is not set unless I explicitely select some language from the menu. So I either have to patch Moodle to always set the session language upon login or change the language setting for all users in the database . This pitfall should be mentioned in the language instructions, particularly those suggesting to create a custom language to overwrite standard translations.
Comment 2: If I understand you correctly: de is not in the langlist, but the files still are available?
Comment 3: Yes, de is no longer in the language list but the language files are there. The purpose of my using custom language (being forced to until the language extensions are implemented; cf http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=24501#115956 ) is to overwrite some of the strings using de as the base language. Having both in the list would be counterproductive. Unfortunately, Moodle acts dumb in this situation. I thought I fixed it by patching the string recall function by forcing it to use my custom language in place of de if stored as default. However, I just ran into a new but related problem. If I still have de as default and edit my profile without setting new preferred langauge, the stored default is set to the first language on the list whatever that happens to be (this bypasses my patch). So, it seems I should just change user records in the database instead of patching the code.
Comment 4: Yes, change the user records: UPDATE user SET lang = 'de_de' WHERE lang = 'de'

Post title: U.S. English - marks vs points
Post description: ```text
Hi,




The language string for 'marks' in U.S. English would be better stated as 'Points'.  'Marks' is not a term normally used in the US for grading.




In /moodle/lang/en_us/quiz.php


$string['marks'] = 'Points';




Also, I think we should consider adding the singular:


$string['mark'] = 'Point';




Any comments?  I had originally opened this as a bug, but it was closed and suggested that it be discussed in forums to see what people thought of it.




Thanks,
```
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I think it is a good idea to discuss changes to the language files in the community before implementing them, especially with languages as widely used as U.S. English. People might be confused when their Moodle after an upgrade suddenly uses different words for the same concepts.
Comment 2: I think that the difference in usage of 'marks' vs 'points' is of about the same level of significance at the 'enrolment'/'enrollment' issue. To Americans, the entire effort receives a 'mark' or 'grade' but the individual items adding up to the total grade are 'points' not 'marks'. Most Americans are probably unaware of the British/Australian usage of the term. Since the total evaluation in both Am. E and Br. E can be called 'Marks' it doesn't seem strange when it is the label of a column in a summary. It's only in cases when we are talking about the total number of marks/points that a specific item should receive that the distinction is important. I vote for replacing the definition in lang/en_us/quiz.php: $string['marks'] = 'Points'; This will still work in Am. E as a column heading.

Post title: RTL vs LTR language setting - Just curious!
Post description: I'm curious as to why there is a setting for specifying the direction of the language for the site.  Isn't this completely predictable from the choice of language?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Yes, you're probably right, and maybe it should be implemented that way. It was actually like that in the early days (back in 2002) but it was most disconcerting having the page flipping over while testing. Also the RTL layout is not quite a mirror image. So I implemented it as a choice for the admin. Are there any situations where Arabic is used LTR? Are there any other RTL languages?
Comment 2: Are there situations where Arabic is used LTR?  I don't know Arabic, but I do know that numbers even embedded in an LTR text are entered and read LTR but the font end processor surely takes care of this automatically. All of the rest of the RTL languages these days are ones based on either the Hebrew or Arabic scripts, Yiddish for the former and Armenian, Kurdish, Farsi, Pashto, Sindhi, and Urdu for the later. There may be some more minor ones in the former Soviet Republics that border the Arabic script-using countries to the south.  Chinese is no longer written RTL, nor is Japanese. Of the above, Farsi (Iran) and Urdu (Pakistan) are good candidates for future language modules since they are national languages with large numbers of computer users.
Comment 3: Thanks, good info! Actually, someone is working on a Farsi translation - I should check how they're going.
Comment 4: Japanese could be RTL, but then you would have to make it TTB (top to bottom)! Martin, I don't think you need any more layout headaches! It will be interesting to see how the other languages Tom pointed out will change. Cheers, ptervin...who is probably BTT more often than not.
